posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked:
My FRC team is having trouble simulating the robot code in VS Code. Whenever we try to run the simulation, the following warning appears:

"Warning at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:433): The robot program quit unexpectedly. This is usually due to a code error."

The error message also mentions that the above stack trace can help identify where the problem occurred. It suggests reviewing the documentation on reading stack traces for more details.

Additionally, another error occurs at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:440), stating that the startCompetition() method or related functions should handle such exceptions.

link_counts.title: Reading Stacktraces — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: You need to scroll up in the output window to see the specific error that is causing your code to crash.

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text, with HTML tags removed and unnecessary elements simplified while preserving the original meaning:

"The robot program experienced an error when attempting to initialize the Swerve module simulation configuration. Specifically, there was a ClassNotFoundException for the file 'org.ironmaple.simulation.drivesims.configs.SwerveModuleSimulationConfig'. This issue occurred during the execution of the SwerveDrive class, which was triggered by the SwerveParser creating the SwerveDrive object. The error propagated through the robot container initialization process, ultimately causing the robot program to terminate unexpectedly. The error stack trace indicates that the issue originated in the class loading mechanism when trying to access the Swerve module configuration."

For the logging information:
- [phoenix] CANbus network connections were successfully established.
- [phoenix] CANbus frames were transmitted and received, but there was a momentary issue with frame validation due to potential stale frames or wiring concerns.
- Warnings indicate that the robot program terminated prematurely, likely due to the unresolved classloading error.

Additional system messages:
- Phoenix diagnostics reported clean shutdown.
- Libraries were shut down gracefully without issues.

link_counts.title: Reading Stacktraces — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Looks like you don't have the MapleSim vendordep installed. It should be available in the WPILib sidebar.

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: No, he is installed on my VS code.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Can you post the contents of .wpilib\wpilib_preferences.json?

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: "Enable Cpp IntelliSense": false, "Current Language": "Java", "Project Year": "2025 Beta", "Team Number": 9485. This is all.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Somehow, you’re using a 2025 version of WPILib with a beta project that hasn’t been imported. VS Code should be prompting you to import your project every time you open it. Because of this, the vendor dependency manager is showing you beta versions of vendor dependencies, and you have mismatched versions. For example, the version of Advantage Kit you have needs WPILib 2025.3.2, but you’re using 2025.1.1, and most of the other vendordeps need beta versions of wpilib. You need to import your project and update all your vendordeps to compatible versions.

link_counts.title: Importing Last Year’s Robot Code — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: I tried doing this in the 2025 competition, but every time the drive station shows 'No Robot Code.' Now that I'm at home, the simulations work correctly, but when I test them on my physical robot, I wonder if errors will occur. Do you know how I can avoid these errors? Again, I apologize for my English; I'm Brazilian.
